awd_titl_txt: Theories for Novel States of Matter Observed and Constructed in Condensed Matter and Cold Atom Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports research and education on developing theories for new states of matter that appear in materials and in systems comprised of arrangements of individual atoms at ultralow temperatures. The quantum mechanical behavior of interacting particles in these systems generates extremely rich physics and conceptual mysteries that continue to demand better and even revolutionary understanding from scientists. Recently, unexpected and exciting discoveries have been made in various condensed matter systems, such as devices made from two graphene sheets that can exhibit superconductivity when the two sheets are precisely stacked at a specific orientation with respect to one another. These systems offer unprecedented tunability and may represent the beginning of a new era of study in quantum many-body physics. Related recent progress in cold-atom experimental techniques allows the exploration of novel physics: under certain conditions, e.g. illumination by laser light of specific characteristics, these systems behave as if they exist in a higher-dimensional space than our usual three dimensions. This PI aims to develop and apply new theoretical concepts and methodologies to study the interplay of quantum mechanics and many-body physics in these platforms, and to develop theories for their manifestations in a variety of phenomena. The research could potentially lead to both new fundamental understanding of nature, and also to technological innovation from harnessing these strictly quantum phenomena. 

The project has potential scientific impact beyond condensed matter physics, as the research is relevant for high-energy physics. The PI expects to interact and collaborate broadly with scientists from related fields. The project will offer opportunities for training and mentoring graduate students and of postdoc researchers, providing them with essential theoretical tools that not only can be applied in physics research within academia but can also find uses in a wide range of industrial settings.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports research and education on unconventional states of matter in condensed-matter and cold-atom systems. The goal of this project is three-fold: i) to describe and understand the recently discovered superconductivity and the weakly correlated insulator phase in moire superlattices via a formalism developed by the PI's group recently, and to also engineer more exotic states of matter in related systems; ii) to construct and understand unconventional states of matter such as strongly interacting topological states and symmetry-protected topological states in high dimensions that can be realized in cold atom systems with synthetic dimensions; iii) to use the exactly soluble Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev physics as the starting point to describe and understand non-Fermi-liquid states and related phenomena that are experimentally observed in high-temperature superconductors.

The project has potential scientific impact beyond condensed matter physics, as the research is relevant for high-energy physics. The PI expects to interact and collaborate broadly with scientists from related fields. The project will offer opportunities for training and mentoring graduate students and of postdoc researchers, providing them with essential theoretical tools that not only can be applied in physics research within academia but can also find uses in a wide range of industrial settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the last review period (08/01/2021 to 07/31/2022), within all the works conducted in my group, there are three publications that I consider are significant outcomes supported by this NSF grant.

The moire heterostructure has proven to be the most exciting platform and testbed for strongly correlated physics in two spatial dimensions. Numerous amazing experimental discoveries have been made in various moire systems. A recent experiment on the transition metal dichalcogenides (TMD) moire heterostructure has reported a continuous interaction-driven metal-insulator transition (MIT), which was thought to be captured by a previous theory developed about 15 years ago. However, our group recognized that there is a major qualitative inconsistency between the experiment and the previous theory: the reported resistivity at the MIT critical point is significantly larger than what would be predicted by the previous theory; in fact the reported critical resistivity is so large that it far exceeds the well accepted universal Mott-Ioffe-Regel limit of ordinary metallic states.

We proposed a very novel theory to explain this exotic experimental puzzle. We proposed that, the electric charge actually fractionalizes at the metal-insulator transition, and we demonstrated that this would be a natural consequence of a minor modification of the foundation of the previous theory. The charge fractionalization would lead to a much larger critical resistivity than what was previously predicted, along with many other experimental consequences as well. After a thorough analysis of our theory, we made a series of predictions, which can be tested by future experiments.

Another outcome of our research, is the designing of an archetype example of quantum states of matter with fractal orders using the platform of ultracold Rydberg atoms. This work was conducted in collaboration with my colleague David Weld, who is an cold atom experimentalist. In the last decade the very notion of symmetry has been extensively generalized, which allowed us to view and understand states of matter with a completely new perspective. Within these generalizations of symmetries, the notion of fractal subsystem symmetry is the most exotic and intriguing one. However, almost all previous studies in this field have been highly focused on theoretical understanding of these states, little progress has been made to the experimental realization of the fractal symmetries.

We believe that in our work we have made by far the most realistic proposal of constructing states of matter with fractal symmetries. The reason that most studies on this subject have been purely theoretical is that, the models with fractal orders usually involve multi-body interactions, while our nature is dominated by two-body interactions. In our work we developed a general method to simulate the physics of multi-spin interactions with the two-body Van der Waals interaction between the Rydberg atoms. We also proposed a series of experiments to detect the structure of the fractal order. The general method we developed also allows us to simulate numerous other models with exotic behaviors such as various topological orders using realistic two-body interactions.

In another piece of work, we developed a parent model that unifies a family of infinite number of models with fractal subsystem symmetries. It turns out that this parent model possesses an exotic symmetry that we named the "Pascal's triangle symmetry", which can be deduced to an infinite series of fractal symmetries. By studying this parent model, we also discovered that there is a multi-critical point that possesses an infinite series of fractal symmetries. We expect that our study paves the way to more general study of critical points and conformal field theories with fractal symmetries in the future.
